16N.1.hl.TZ0.40.excerpt: Which property explains why tetramethylsilane, Si(CH3)4, can be used as a reference standard in 1H NMR spectroscopy?A. It has a high boiling point.B. It is a reactive compound.C. All its protons are in the same chemical environment.D. It gives multiple signals.

questions.content:
Which property explains why tetramethylsilane, Si(CH3)4, can be used as a reference standard in 1H NMR spectroscopy?


A. It has a high boiling point.


B. It is a reactive compound.


C. All its protons are in the same chemical environment.


D. It gives multiple signals.

16N.2.hl.TZ0.1f.excerpt: Predict the 1HNMR data for ethanedioic acid and ethane-1,2-diol by completing the table.
specification: Ethane-1,2-diol, HOCH2CH2OH, has a wide variety of uses including the removal of ice from aircraft and heat transfer in a solar cell.

questions.content:
(i) Calculate ΔHθ, in kJ, for this similar reaction below using \(\Delta H_{\rm{f}}^\theta \) data from section 12 of the data booklet. \(\Delta H_{\rm{f}}^\theta \) of HOCH2CH2OH(l) is –454.8kJmol-1.


2CO (g) + 3H2 (g) \( \rightleftharpoons \) HOCH2CH2OH (l)


(ii) Deduce why the answers to (a)(iii) and (b)(i) differ.


(iii) ΔSθ for the reaction in (b)(i) is –620.1JK-1. Comment on the decrease in entropy.


(iv) Calculate the value of ΔGθ, in kJ, for this reaction at 298 K using your answer to (b)(i). (If you did not obtain an answer to (b)(i), use –244.0 kJ, but this is not the correct value.)


(v) Comment on the statement that the reaction becomes less spontaneous as temperature is increased.
questions.label: b
markscheme:
i
«ΔH = Σ ΔHf products –ΣΔHf reactants = –454.8 kJ mol-1– 2(–110.5 kJ mol-1) =» –233.8 «kJ»

ii
in (a)(iii) gas is formed and in (b)(i) liquid is formed
OR
products are in different states
OR
conversion of gas to liquid is exothermic
OR
conversion of liquid to gas is endothermic
OR
enthalpy of vapourisation needs to be taken into account

Accept product is «now» a liquid.
Accept answers referring to bond enthalpies being means/averages.

iii
«ΔS is negative because five mols of» gases becomes «one mol of» liquid
OR
increase in complexity of product «compared to reactants»
OR
product more ordered «than reactants»
Accept “fewer moles of gas” but not “fewer molecules”.

Award [2] for correct final answer.
Award [1 max] for «+»185 × 103.

If –244.0 kJ used, answer is:
ΔG = –244.0 kJ –(298 K \(\left( {\frac{{ - 620.1}}{{1000}}} \right)\)kJ K-1) = –59.2 «kJ»
Award [2] for correct final answer.

v
increasing T makes ΔG larger/more positive/less negative
OR
–TΔS will increase

questions.content: Predict the 1HNMR data for ethanedioic acid and ethane-1,2-diol by completing the table.
questions.label: f

17M.2.hl.TZ1.6b.iii.excerpt: Explain why tetramethylsilane (TMS) is often used as a reference standard in 1H NMR.
specification: This question is about carbon and chlorine compounds.

questions.content: Ethane, \({{\text{C}}_{\text{2}}}{{\text{H}}_{\text{6}}}\), reacts with chlorine in sunlight. State the type of this reaction and the name of the mechanism by which it occurs.
questions.label: a
markscheme: Award [1] for “«free-»radical substitution”or “SR” written anywhere in the answer.

questions.content: Formulate equations for the two propagation steps and one termination step in the formation of chloroethane from ethane.
questions.label: b.i
markscheme: Allow ECF for incorrect radicalsproduced in propagation step for M3.

questions.content: Deduce the splitting patterns in the 1H NMR spectrum of C2H5Cl.
questions.label: b.ii

questions.content: Explain why tetramethylsilane (TMS) is often used as a reference standard in 1H NMR.
questions.label: b.iii
markscheme: chemical shift/signal outside range of common chemical shift/signal

strong signal/12/all H atoms in same environment
OR
singlet/no splitting of the signal
contains three common NMR nuclei/1H and 13C and 29Si

questions.content:
One possible product, X, of the reaction of ethane with chlorine has the following composition by mass:


carbon: 24.27%, hydrogen: 4.08%, chlorine: 71.65%


Determine the empirical formula of the product.
questions.label: c.i

questions.content: The mass and 1H NMR spectra of product X are shown below. Deduce, giving your reasons, its structural formula and hence the name of the compound.
questions.label: c.ii
markscheme:
two signals «in 1H NMR spectrum» AND«so» CH3CHCl2
OR
«signals in» 3:1 ratio «in 1H NMR spectrum» AND «so» CH3CHCl2
OR
one doublet and one quartet «in 1H NMR spectrum» AND «so» CH3CHCl2
Allow ECF for a correct name for M3 ifan incorrect chlorohydrocarbon is identified.

questions.content: When the product X is reacted with NaOH in a hot alcoholic solution, C2H3Cl is formed. State the role of the reactant NaOH other than as a nucleophile.
questions.label: c.iii

questions.content: Chloroethene, \({{\text{C}}_{\text{2}}}{{\text{H}}_{\text{3}}}{\text{Cl}}\), can undergo polymerization. Draw a section of the polymer with three repeating units.
questions.label: d
markscheme: Accept other versions of the polymer,such as head to head and head to tail.
Accept condensed structure provided allC to C bonds are shown (as single).

questions.content: Outline, in terms of the bonding present, why the reaction conditions of halogenation are different for alkanes and benzene.
questions.label: c.ii
markscheme: benzene has «delocalized» \(\pi \) bonds «that are susceptible to electrophile attack»AND alkanes do not

questions.content:
Below are two isomers, A and B, with the molecular formula C4H9Br.



Explain the mechanism of the nucleophilic substitution reaction with NaOH(aq) for the isomer that reacts almost exclusively by an SN2 mechanism using curly arrows to represent the movement of electron pairs.
questions.label: d
markscheme: curly arrow going from lone pair/negative charge on O in –OH to C
representation of transition state showing negative charge, square brackets andpartial bonds
Accept OH– with or without the lonepair.
Do not allow curly arrows originating onH in OH–.
Do not penalize if HO and Br are not at180°.
Do not award M3 if OH–C bond isrepresented.
Award [2 max] if wrong isomer is used.

20N.2.hl.TZ0.1d(v).excerpt: Deduce the number of signals and chemical shifts with splitting patterns in the 1H NMR spectrum of ethoxyethane. Use section 27 of the data booklet.
specification: Chlorine undergoes many reactions.

2.67 g of manganese(IV) oxide was added to 200.0 cm3 of 2.00 mol dm-3 HCl.
MnO2 (s)+4HCl (aq)→Cl2 (g)+2H2O (l)+MnCl2 (aq)

Chlorine gas reacts with water to produce hypochlorous acid and hydrochloric acid.
Cl2 (g)+H2O (l)⇌HClO (aq)+HCl (aq)
CCl2F2 is a common chlorofluorocarbon, CFC.

questions.content: State the full electron configuration of the chlorine atom.
questions.label: a(i)

questions.content: State, giving a reason, whether the chlorine atom or the chloride ion has a larger radius.
questions.label: a(ii)
markscheme: Accept Cl- AND has an extra electron.

questions.content: Outline why the chlorine atom has a smaller atomic radius than the sulfur atom.
questions.label: a(iii)
markscheme: Cl has a greater nuclear charge/number of protons/Zeff «causing a stronger pull on the outer electrons» ✔

questions.content:
The mass spectrum of chlorine is shown.



NIST Mass Spectrometry Data Center Collection © 2014 copyright by the U.S. Secretary of Commerce on behalf of the United States of America. All rights reserved.



Outline the reason for the two peaks at m/z=35 and 37.
questions.label: a(iv)

questions.content: Explain the presence and relative abundance of the peak at m/z=74.
questions.label: a(v)
markscheme:
chlorine-37 is the least abundant «isotope»
OR
low probability of twoCl37 «isotopes» occurring in a molecule ✔

questions.content: Calculate the amount, in mol, of manganese(IV) oxide added.
questions.label: b(i)

questions.content: Determine the limiting reactant, showing your calculations.
questions.label: b(ii)
markscheme: Accept other valid methods of determining the limiting reactant in M2.

questions.content: Determine the excess amount, in mol, of the other reactant.
questions.label: b(iii)

questions.content: Calculate the volume of chlorine, in dm3, produced if the reaction is conducted at standard temperature and pressure (STP). Use section 2 of the data booklet.
questions.label: b(iv)

questions.content: State the oxidation state of manganese in MnO2 and MnCl2.
questions.label: b(v)

questions.content: Deduce, referring to oxidation states, whether MnO2 is an oxidizing or reducing agent.
questions.label: b(vi)
markscheme: oxidizing agent AND oxidation state of Mn changes from +4 to +2/decreases ✔

questions.content: Hypochlorous acid is considered a weak acid. Outline what is meant by the term weak acid.
questions.label: c(i)

questions.content: State the formula of the conjugate base of hypochlorous acid.
questions.label: c(ii)

questions.content: Calculate the concentration of H+ (aq) in a HClO aq solution with a pH=3.61.
questions.label: c(iii)

questions.content: State the type of reaction occurring when ethane reacts with chlorine to produce chloroethane.
questions.label: d(i)
markscheme: Do not accept electrophilic or nucleophilic substitution.

questions.content: Predict, giving a reason, whether ethane or chloroethane is more reactive.
questions.label: d(ii)
markscheme:
chloroethane AND C–Clbond is weaker/324 kJ mol−1 than C–Hbond/414 kJ mol−1
OR
chloroethane AND contains a polar bond ✔

questions.content: Explain the mechanism of the reaction between chloroethane and aqueous sodium hydroxide, NaOH (aq), using curly arrows to represent the movement of electron pairs.
questions.label: d(iii)
markscheme: curly arrow going from lone pair/negative charge on O in −OHto C ✔
representation of transition state showing negative charge, square brackets and partial bonds ✔
Accept OH- with or without the lone pair.
Do not accept curly arrows originating on H in OH-.
Accept curly arrows in the transition state.
Do not penalize if HO and Cl are not at 180°.
Do not award M3 if OH-C bond is represented.

questions.content:
Ethoxyethane (diethyl ether) can be used as a solvent for this conversion.
Draw the structural formula of ethoxyethane
questions.label: d(iv)

questions.content: Deduce the number of signals and chemical shifts with splitting patterns in the 1H NMR spectrum of ethoxyethane. Use section 27 of the data booklet.
questions.label: d(v)
markscheme: Award [1] for two correct chemical shifts or two correct splitting patterns.

questions.content: Calculate the percentage by mass of chlorine in CCl2F2.
questions.label: e(i)

questions.content: Comment on how international cooperation has contributed to the lowering of CFC emissions responsible for ozone depletion.
questions.label: e(ii)
markscheme:
research «collaboration» for alternative technologies «to replace CFCs»
OR
technologies «developed»/data could be shared
OR
political pressure/Montreal Protocol/governments passing legislations ✔
Do not accept any reference to CFC as greenhouse gas or product of fossil fuel combustion.
Accept reference to specific measures, such as agreement on banning use/manufacture of CFCs.

questions.content: CFCs produce chlorine radicals. Write two successive propagation steps to show how chlorine radicals catalyse the depletion of ozone.
questions.label: e(iii)

allows them to explain the properties of different compounds/substances
OR
enables them to generalise about substances
OR
enables them to make predictions ✔

questions.content: Explain why the major organic product is 2-bromopropane and not 1-bromopropane.

markscheme:
«2-bromopropane involves» formation of more stable «secondary» carbocation/carbonium ion/intermediate
OR
1-bromopropane involves formation of less stable «primary» carbocation/carbonium ion/intermediate ✔
«increased» positive inductive/electron-releasing effect of extra–R group/–CH3/methyl «increases stability of secondary carbocation» ✔
Award [1] for “more stable due to positive inductive effect”.
Do not award marks for quoting Markovnikov’s rule without any explanation.

questions.content:
The structural formula of urea is shown.



Predict the electron domain and molecular geometries at the nitrogen and carbon atoms, applying the VSEPR theory.
questions.label: b
markscheme: Note: Urea’s structure is more complexthan that predicted from VSEPR theory.

questions.content:
Urea can be made by reacting potassium cyanate, KNCO, with ammonium chloride, NH4Cl.


KNCO(aq) + NH4Cl(aq) → (H2N)2CO(aq) + KCl(aq)


Determine the maximum mass of urea that could be formed from 50.0 cm3 of 0.100 mol dm−3 potassium cyanate solution.
questions.label: c

questions.content: State the equilibrium constant expression, Kc.
questions.label: d.i

questions.content: Predict, with a reason, the effect on the equilibrium constant, Kc, when the temperature is increased.
questions.label: d.ii

questions.content: Determine an approximate order of magnitude for Kc, using sections 1 and 2 of the data booklet. Assume ΔGΘ for the forward reaction is approximately +50 kJ at 298 K.
questions.label: d.iii

questions.content: Suggest one reason why urea is a solid and ammonia a gas at room temperature.
questions.label: e.i
markscheme: urea is more polar/has greater dipole moment
Accept “urea has larger size/greatervan der Waals forces”.

questions.content: Sketch two different hydrogen bonding interactions between ammonia and water.
questions.label: e.ii
markscheme: If lone pairs are shown on N or O, thenthe lone pair on N or one of the lonepairs on O MUST be involved in theH-bond.
Penalize solid line to representH-bonding only once.

questions.content:
The combustion of urea produces water, carbon dioxide and nitrogen.


Formulate a balanced equation for the reaction.
questions.label: f

questions.content: Calculate the maximum volume of CO2, in cm3, produced at STP by the combustion of 0.600 g of urea, using sections 2 and 6 of the data booklet.
questions.label: g

questions.content: Describe the bond formation when urea acts as a ligand in a transition metal complex ion.
questions.label: h
markscheme: lone/non-bonding electron pairs «on nitrogen/oxygen/ligand» given to/shared withmetal ion

questions.content: The C–N bonds in urea are shorter than might be expected for a single C–N bond. Suggest, in terms of electrons, how this could occur.
questions.label: i
markscheme: lone pairs on nitrogen atoms can be donated to/shared with C–N bond
slight positive charge on C due to C=O polarity reduces C–N bond length

questions.content:
The mass spectrum of urea is shown below.



Identify the species responsible for the peaks at m/z = 60 and 44.
questions.label: j

questions.content:
The IR spectrum of urea is shown below.



Identify the bonds causing the absorptions at 3450 cm−1 and 1700 cm−1 using section 26 of the data booklet.
questions.label: k

questions.content: Predict the number of signals in the 1H NMR spectrum of urea.
questions.label: l.i

questions.content: Predict the splitting pattern of the 1H NMR spectrum of urea.
questions.label: l.ii

questions.content: Outline why TMS (tetramethylsilane) may be added to the sample to carry out 1H NMR spectroscopy and why it is particularly suited to this role.
questions.label: l.iii
markscheme: signal is well away from other absorptions

18M.1.hl.TZ1.40.excerpt: Which would be the most effective method to distinguish between liquid propan-1-ol and...

questions.content:
Which would be the most effective method to distinguish between liquid propan-1-ol and propan-2-ol?


A.     Observation of colour change when warmed with acidified potassium dichromate


B.     Determination of m/z value of molecular ion in the mass spectrum


C.     Determination of percentage composition


D.     1H NMR spectroscopy

18M.2.hl.TZ1.1l.iii.excerpt: Outline why TMS (tetramethylsilane) may be added to the sample to carry out 1H NMR spectroscopy and why it is particularly suited to this role.
specification: Urea, (H2N)2CO, is excreted by mammals and can be used as a fertilizer.

Urea can also be made by the direct combination of ammonia and carbon dioxide gases.
2NH3(g) + CO2(g) \( \rightleftharpoons \) (H2N)2CO(g) + H2O(g)     ΔH < 0

«cost» increases AND inefficient/too much/about half mass not nitrogen

18M.2.hl.TZ2.9a.ii.excerpt: Mass spectra A and B of the two isomers are given.Explain which spectrum is produced by each compound using section 28 of the data booklet.
specification:
Organic compounds often have isomers.
A straight chain molecule of formula C5H10O contains a carbonyl group. The compound cannot be oxidized by acidified potassium dichromate(VI) solution.
A tertiary halogenoalkane with three different alkyl groups, (R1R2R3)C−X, undergoes a SN1 reaction and forms two isomers.

questions.content: Deduce the structural formulas of the two possible isomers.
questions.label: a.i

questions.content:
Mass spectra A and B of the two isomers are given.



Explain which spectrum is produced by each compound using section 28 of the data booklet.
questions.label: a.ii
markscheme: Accept “CH3COCH2CH2CH3 byelimination since fragment CH3CO is notlisted” for M2.

questions.content: State the type of bond fission that takes place in a SN1 reaction.
questions.label: b.i

questions.content: State the type of solvent most suitable for the reaction.
questions.label: b.ii

questions.content: Draw the structure of the intermediate formed stating its shape.
questions.label: b.iii

questions.content: Suggest, giving a reason, the percentage of each isomer from the SN1 reaction.
questions.label: b.iv
markscheme: nucleophile can attack from either side «of the planar carbocation»

questions.content:
Nitrobenzene, C6H5NO2, can be converted to phenylamine via a two-stage reaction.


In the first stage, nitrobenzene is reduced with tin in an acidic solution to form an intermediate ion and tin(II) ions. In the second stage, the intermediate ion is converted to phenylamine in the presence of hydroxide ions.


Formulate the equation for each stage of the reaction.
questions.label: c

18M.3.hl.TZ2.27b.excerpt: Predict the chemical shifts and integration for each signal in the 1H NMR spectrum for ethanol using section 27 of the data booklet.
specification: Ethanol can be detected by a variety of instruments.

questions.content:
Fuel cells use an electrochemical process to determine the concentration of ethanol.


Formulate the overall equation for this process.
questions.label: a
markscheme: Accept any correct formula for reactantsand products.

questions.content: Predict the chemical shifts and integration for each signal in the 1H NMR spectrum for ethanol using section 27 of the data booklet.
questions.label: b
markscheme: For each chemical shift accept a specificvalue within the range.
Assignment of proton to fragment(eg, R–OH) is not required in each case.

21N.1.hl.TZ0.40.excerpt: Which substance has the following 1H NMR spectrum?SDBS, National Institute of Advanced...

questions.content:
Which substance has the following 1H NMR spectrum?



SDBS, National Institute of Advanced Science and Technology.



A.  Propane


B.  Propanal


C.  Butanoic acid


D.  Ethyl ethanoate

The following spectrums show the Infrared spectra of propan-1-ol, propanal and propanoic acid.

22M.2.hl.TZ1.6b(iii).excerpt: Deduce the number of signals that you would expect in the 1H NMR spectrum of nitrobenzene and the relative areas of these.
specification: Nitric acid is usually produced by the oxidation of ammonia.
A mixture of nitric acid and sulfuric acid can be used to convert benzene to nitrobenzene, C6H5NO2.

questions.content: Draw arrows in the boxes to represent the electron configuration of a nitrogen atom.
questions.label: a(i)
markscheme: Accept half arrows instead of full arrows.

questions.content: Deduce a Lewis (electron dot) structure of the nitric acid molecule, HNO3, that obeys the octet rule, showing any non-zero formal charges on the atoms.
questions.label: a(ii)
markscheme: Accept dots, crosses or lines to represent electron pairs.
Do not accept resonance structures with delocalised bonds/electrons.
Do not accept a bond between nitrogen and hydrogen.
For an incorrect Lewis structure, allow ECF for non-zero formal charges.

questions.content: Explain the relative lengths of the three bonds between N and O in nitric acid.
questions.label: a(iii)
markscheme: Award [2 max] if bond strength, rather than bond length discussed.
Accept N-O between single and double bond AND N-OH single bond.

questions.content: State a technique used to determine the length of the bonds between N and O in solid HNO3.
questions.label: a(iv)

questions.content: Write an equation for the reaction between the acids to produce the electrophile, NO2+.
questions.label: b(i)
markscheme: Accept “HNO3 + H2SO4⇌ H2NO3+ + HSO4-” AND “H2NO3+⇌ NO2+ + H2O”.
Accept single arrows instead of equilibrium signs.

questions.content: Draw the structural formula of the carbocation intermediate produced when this electrophile attacks benzene.
questions.label: b(ii)
markscheme: Do not accept structures missing the positive charge.

questions.content: Deduce the number of signals that you would expect in the 1H NMR spectrum of nitrobenzene and the relative areas of these.
questions.label: b(iii)

22M.2.hl.TZ2.8e(ii).excerpt: Deduce the splitting pattern in the 1H NMR spectrum for 1-bromopropane.
specification: Carbon forms many compounds.
C60 and diamond are allotropes of carbon.

Chlorine reacts with methane.
CH4 (g) + Cl2 (g) → CH3Cl (g) + HCl (g)

questions.content: Outline two differences between the bonding of carbon atoms in C60 and diamond.
questions.label: a(i)
markscheme: C60 fullerene: bonded to 3 C AND diamond: bonded to 4 C ✔
C60 fullerene: delocalized/resonance AND diamond: not delocalized / no resonance ✔
Accept "bonds in fullerene are shorter/stronger/have higher bond order OR bonds in diamond longer/weaker/have lower bond order".

questions.content: Explain why C60 and diamond sublime at different temperatures and pressures.
questions.label: a(ii)
markscheme: diamond giant/network covalent AND sublimes at higher temperature ✔
Accept “diamond has strong covalent bonds AND require more energy to break «than intermolecular forces»” for M1.

questions.content: State two features showing that propane and butane are members of the same homologous series.
questions.label: b

questions.content: Describe a test and the expected result to indicate the presence of carbon–carbon double bonds.
questions.label: c

questions.content: Draw the full structural formula of (Z)-but-2-ene.
questions.label: d(i)

questions.content: Write the equation for the reaction between but-2-ene and hydrogen bromide.
questions.label: d(ii)
markscheme: Accept molecular formulas for bothreactants and product

questions.content: State the type of reaction.
questions.label: d(iii)
markscheme: Do not accept nucleophilic or free radical addition.

questions.content: Suggest two differences in the 1H NMR of but-2-ene and the organic product from (d)(ii).
questions.label: d(iv)
markscheme: product: «has signal at» 3.5-4.4 ppm «and but-2-ene: does not» ✔
but-2-ene: «has signal at» 4.5-6.0 ppm «and product: does not» ✔
Accept “product «has signal at» 1.3–1.4 ppm «and but-2-ene: does not»”.

questions.content: Predict, giving a reason, the major product of reaction between but-1-ene and steam.
questions.label: d(v)
markscheme: Do not accept “Markovnikov’s rule” without reference to carbocation stability.

questions.content: Explain the mechanism of the reaction between 1-bromopropane, CH3CH2CH2Br, and aqueous sodium hydroxide, NaOH (aq), using curly arrows to represent the movement of electron pairs.
questions.label: e(i)
markscheme: curly arrow going from lone pair/negative charge on O in HO– to C ✔
representation of transition state showing negative charge, square brackets andpartial bonds ✔
Do not allow curly arrow originating on H in HO–.

Accept curly arrow either going from bond between C and Br to Br in 1-bromopropane or in the transition
state.
Do not penalize if HO and Br are not at 180° to each other.

questions.content: Deduce the splitting pattern in the 1H NMR spectrum for 1-bromopropane.
questions.label: e(ii)

questions.content: Calculate the enthalpy change of the reaction, ΔH, using section 11 of the data booklet.
questions.label: f(i)
markscheme:
bond breaking: C–H + Cl–Cl / 414 «kJ mol–1» + 242 «kJ mol–1»/656 «kJ»
OR
bond breaking: 4C–H + Cl–Cl / 4 × 414 «kJ mol–1» + 242 «kJ mol–1» / 1898 «kJ» ✔

bond forming: «C–Cl + H–Cl / 324 kJ mol–1 + 431 kJ mol–1» / 755 «kJ»
OR
bond forming: «3C–H + C–Cl + H–Cl / 3 × 414 «kJ mol–1» + 324 «kJ mol–1» + 431 kJ mol–1» / 1997 «kJ» ✔
«ΔH = bond breaking – bond forming = 656 kJ – 755 kJ» = –99 «kJ» ✔

questions.content: Draw and label an enthalpy level diagram for this reaction.
questions.label: f(ii)
markscheme:
ΔH/-99 «kJ» labelled on arrow from reactants to products
OR
activation energy/Ea labelled on arrow from reactant to top of energy profile ✔
Accept a double headed arrow between reactants and products labelled as ΔH for M2.

19M.2.hl.TZ1.2a.excerpt: Identify the wavenumber of one peak in the IR spectrum of benzoic acid, using section 26 of the data booklet.
specification: Benzoic acid, C6H5COOH, is another derivative of benzene.

questions.content: Identify the wavenumber of one peak in the IR spectrum of benzoic acid, using section 26 of the data booklet.
questions.label: a
markscheme:
Any wavenumber in the following ranges:
2500−3000 «cm−1» [✔]
1700−1750 «cm−1» [✔]
2850−3090 «cm−1» [✔]

questions.content: Identify the spectroscopic technique that is used to measure the bond lengths in solid benzoic acid.
questions.label: b

questions.content: Outline one piece of physical evidence for the structure of the benzene ring.
questions.label: c
markscheme:
all «H–C–C/C-C-C» angles equal/120º [✔]
all C–C bond lengths equal/intermediate between double and single

questions.content: Draw the structure of the conjugate base of benzoic acid showing all the atoms and all the bonds.
questions.label: d
markscheme:
Note:Accept Kekulé structures.
Negative sign must be shown in correct position.

questions.content: Outline why both C to O bonds in the conjugate base are the same length and suggest a value for them. Use section 10 of the data booklet.
questions.label: e
markscheme: 122 «pm»< C–O< 143 «pm» [✔]

Note:Accept “delocalized π-bond”.
Accept “bond intermediate between single and double bond” or “bond order 1.5” for M1.
Accept any answer in range 123 to 142 pm.

questions.content: The pH of an aqueous solution of benzoic acid at 298 K is 2.95. Determine the concentration of hydroxide ions in the solution, using section 2 of the data booklet.
questions.label: f(i)
markscheme: «[OH−] = 1.00 × 10 − 14 mo l 2 d m − 6 1.22 × 10 − 3 mol d m − 3 =» 8.91× 10−12 «mol dm−3» [✔]

ALTERNATIVE 2:
pOH = «14 − 2.95 =» 11.05 [✔]
«[OH−] = 10−11.05 =» 8.91× 10−12 «mol dm−3» [✔]

Note:Award [2] for correct final answer.
Accept other methods.

questions.content: Formulate the equation for the complete combustion of benzoic acid in oxygen using only integer coefficients.
questions.label: f(ii)

questions.content: The combustion reaction in (f)(ii) can also be classed as redox. Identify the atom that is oxidized and the atom that is reduced.
questions.label: g

questions.content: Suggest how benzoic acid, Mr = 122.13, forms an apparent dimer, Mr = 244.26, when dissolved in a non-polar solvent such as hexane.
questions.label: h

questions.content: State the reagent used to convert benzoic acid to phenylmethanol (benzyl alcohol), C6H5CH2OH.
questions.label: i

specification: Ethyne, C2H2, reacts with oxygen in welding torches.

Ethyne reacts with steam.
C2H2 (g) + H2O (g) → C2H4O (g)
Two possible products are:
Product B, CH3CHO, can also be synthesized from ethanol.

questions.content: Write an equation for the complete combustion of ethyne.
questions.label: a
markscheme: 2C2H2 (g) + 5O2 (g) → 4CO2 (g) + 2H2O (l) [✔]

questions.content: Deduce the Lewis (electron dot) structure of ethyne.
questions.label: b(i)
markscheme: Note:Accept any valid combination of lines, dots and crosses.

questions.content: Compare, giving a reason, the length of the bond between the carbon atoms in ethyne with that in ethane, C2H6.
questions.label: b(ii)
markscheme: «ethyne» shorter AND a greater number of shared/bonding electrons

questions.content: Identify the type of interaction that must be overcome when liquid ethyne vaporizes.
questions.label: b(iii)

questions.content: State the name of product B, applying IUPAC rules.
questions.label: c(i)

questions.content: Determine the enthalpy change for the reaction, in kJ, to produce A using section 11 of the data booklet.
questions.label: c(ii)
markscheme:
«sum of bond enthalpies of reactants =» 2(C—H)+C ≡ C + 2(O—H)
OR
2 × 414 «kJ mol-1» + 839 «kJ mol-1» + 2 × 463 «kJ mol-1»
OR
2593 «kJ» [✔]

«sum of bond enthalpies of A =» 3(C—H) + C=C + C—O + O—H
OR
3 × 414 «kJ mol-1» + 614 «kJ mol-1» + 358 «kJ mol-1» + 463 «kJ mol-1»
OR
2677 «kJ» [✔]
«enthalpy of reaction = 2593 kJ – 2677 kJ» = –84 «kJ» [✔]
Note:Award [3] for correct final answer.

questions.content:
The enthalpy change for the reaction to produce B is −213 kJ.


Predict, giving a reason, which product is the most stable.
questions.label: c(iii)
markscheme: B AND it has a more negative/lower enthalpy/«potential» energy
B AND more exothermic «enthalpy of reaction from same starting point» [✔]

questions.content:
The IR spectrum and low resolution 1H NMR spectrum of the actual product formed are shown.



Deduce whether the product is A or B, using evidence from these spectra together with sections 26 and 27 of the  data booklet.


Identity of product:


One piece of evidence from IR:


One piece of evidence from 1H NMR:
questions.label: c(iv)
markscheme:
IR spectrum:
1700–1750 «cm–1 band» AND carbonyl/CO group present
OR
no «band at» 1620–1680 «cm–1» AND absence of double bond/C=C
OR
no «broad band at» 3200–3600 «cm–1 » AND absence of hydroxyl/OH group [✔]

1H NMR spectrum:
«only» two signals AND A would have three
OR
«signal at» 9.4–10.0 «ppm» AND «H atom/proton of» aldehyde/–CHO present
OR
«signal at» 2.2–2.7 «ppm» AND «H atom/proton of alkyl/CH next to» aldehyde/CHO present
OR
«signal at» 2.2–2.7 «ppm» AND «H atom/proton of» RCOCH2- present
OR
no «signal at» 4.5–6.0 «ppm» AND absence of «H atom/proton next to» double bond/C=C ✔
Note:Accept a specific value or range of wavenumbers and chemical shifts.

questions.content: Deduce the average oxidation state of carbon in product B.
questions.label: d(ii)

questions.content: Explain why product B is water soluble.
questions.label: d(iii)
markscheme: has an oxygen/O atom with a lone pair [✔]
that can form hydrogen bonds/H-bonds «with water molecules» [✔]
hydrocarbon chain is short «so does not disrupt many H-bonds with water molecules» [✔]
«large permanent» dipole-dipole interactions with water [✔]

19N.3.hl.TZ0.7.excerpt: X-ray crystallography of a metal crystal produces a diffraction pattern of bright spots.Using X-rays of wavelength 1.54 × 10−10 m, the first bright spots were produced at an angle θ of 22.3° from the centre.Calculate the separation between planes of atoms in the lattice, in meters, using section 1 of the data booklet.

questions.content:
X-ray crystallography of a metal crystal produces a diffraction pattern of bright spots.



Using X-rays of wavelength 1.54 × 10−10 m, the first bright spots were produced at an angle θ of 22.3° from the centre.


Calculate the separation between planes of atoms in the lattice, in meters, using section 1 of the data booklet.
